title: Why remove my comments for "harassment and insults"?
body:
https://i.imgur.com/SF2vonF.png

If this qualifies as harassment and insults then I'd rather have some new mods here. Quoting someone isn't harassment, asking a question to verify if we're talking about the same person is not an insult. You wanna know what's harassment? If I followed this person via their profile to insult them on every comment/post they made. Wanna know what's an insult? If I said something like "You don't even play League because you're shit at this game", which I wouldn't do, but apparently this is just as bad 🤷‍♂️ not gonna name anyone, mod or poster, but I think it's time someone reevaluates some of the mods and how they handle some of the posters on here.

replies.body:
From the context it's pretty clear that you're basically playing a game of "let's call out a specific boards member without saying their name" with another poster, which isn't something that is really okay here. 

The **Naming & Shaming** rule doesn't actually require you to ***name*** a specific person, and using other identifiers in an attempt to identify a single person for negative purposes falls into the category of naming/shaming.

I'm not sure I'd have called this *harassment* personally (I'd probably have cited the Naming & Shaming rule), but I can't say I think the removal was incorrect.

> The Naming & Shaming rule doesn't actually require you to name a specific person

That sounds like a sentence straight out of 1984. There is a reason it's called NAME and shame. Because you have to NAME someone or something to actually shame it.

From what it looks like, it's more like 'Guess Who then Shame' which is actually resorting to the same thing as 'Naming and Shaming'. It does not matter who you conclude who the person in question is after back and forth attempts to name an unknown, you still come to a conclusion to find one and only one player to target with shaming. They might not be the same person in the minds involved with the discussion you still bring upon a type of 'witch hunt' that tries to find and harass someone with shame.

Good thing Issac Asimov thinks 1984 is horseshit.

Implying someone's name is just the same as saying it, without saying it. People will catch on and understand what you mean.

As the person who wrote the updated rules, we kept it called that because it's clear in the majority of circumstances and takes less time to write than "Identifying an individual in any manner intended to shame them for their posting habits, gameplay habits, or other behavioral actions." The text of the rule itself makes no mention of an actual name being required -- if you called me, for example, "that Herald who posts on *Discuss the Boards* all the time" in a post intended to shame me that would be a violation of the rules.

Actually, according to the riot rules that is not naming or shaming. No where in that statement did he call out the individual player. Actually, it's common in contract law for any lack of clarity to be held against the party that wrote the contract.

> Harassment is continuous by the way. not single use, so it's neither named nor harassment.

From the EEOC (which is the template for a great many states' harassment laws):

>Harassment is unwelcome conduct that is based on race, color, religion, sex (including pregnancy), national origin, age (40 or older), disability or genetic information. Harassment becomes unlawful where 1) enduring the offensive conduct becomes a condition of continued employment, or 2) the conduct is **severe or pervasive** enough to create a work environment that a reasonable person would consider **intimidating, hostile, or abusive**.

The key terms here are "severe or pervasive" and "intimidating, hostile, or abusive", at least with regard to the Boards. We generally consider any behavior that has the net effect of discouraging others from using the Boards as "hostile".
Yes, and the above fails to meet these criteria and thus didn't break any rules or laws. Let's move on.

Unless I'm remembering wrong, the rules state these are name and shame

-Personal attacks
-Posts that accuse others of causing a negative in-game experience
-Posts targeted at witch-hunting / naming and shaming
-Posts accusing others of malicious activity
-Posts that accuse others of cheating or using illegal services
-Posts accusing others of trolling on the Boards

Quoting them isn't a personal attack, it's the basis of a discussion. 

>

But they haven't identified him, nobody has named him to my knowledge. And some board members are just more well known that we assume it's X or Y or Z. If you said "A certain morde main" I would assume it was Malicious Metal posting it. My comment falls under none of the categories. 

* I didn't name him and attack him as a person, I was waiting for him to comment it, whether I agree or disagree with it. 
* I didn't accuse him of anything in-game.
* Not witch hunting, I'm not asking for some sort of punishment or telling people to mass downvote and report his posts, didn't name him either.
* Didn't accuse him of being malicious.
* Didn't accuse him of cheating or using any illegal services.
* Didn't accuse him of trolling, despite some people claiming he is, I think he's very naive but that's not something you can punish someone for.

> [{quoted}](name=General Esdeath ,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=1Qq7fEYo,comment-id=0000000200000000,timestamp=2019-10-24T21:12:43.646+0000)But they haven't identified him, nobody has named him to my knowledge.

Effectively identifying the individual is, for all practical purposes, the same as naming them.

>If you said "A certain morde main" I would assume it was Malicious Metal posting it.

And if you'd said "now all we need is a certain Morde main to [come in here and post something problematic/annoying/etc]" we're probably have removed that as well.

>My comment falls under none of the categories. 

None of the categories *can* be all-encompassing. The first rule is moderator discretion for a reason, and that reason is because edge-cases occur and we can't cover all attempts (accidental or intentional) to push the limits of the written rules no matter how well those rules are written.

> [{quoted}](name=The Djinn,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=1Qq7fEYo,comment-id=00000002000000000000,timestamp=2019-10-24T21:16:45.732+0000)
> None of the categories *can* be all-encompassing.

This is a cheap cop-out. 
What it boils down to is "the moderator in question didn't like what he/she read and deleted the post" and that's a problem. This is a public forum and there needs to be some sort of ruleset and most of the mods on here enforce them to a more or less satisfying point.

The problem moderators are the 1-2 snowflakes who are starting to become trigger happy the second they see an instance of "fuck" in a post, even though it's merely to emphasize a point.

> [{quoted}](name=Lauchmelder,realm=EUW,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=1Qq7fEYo,comment-id=000000020000000000000000,timestamp=2019-10-24T22:59:45.855+0000)This is a cheap cop-out. 

Having over a decade of experience moderating various boards and forums, I can assure you it isn't. If you do not have rules that allow for discretion then your rules are either *always* too vague or *always* subject to players continuing to push them as far as possible and claiming immunity from the letter of the law. It creates issues every place I've seen in done.

> What it boils down to is "the moderator in question didn't like what he/she read and deleted the post" and that's a problem.

I've seen this happen once or twice when someone lets a personal opinion weigh too heavily on their judgment. I've overturned those instances. I have no problem overturning moderator actions I feel were improperly done.

> The problem moderators are the 1-2 snowflakes who are starting to become trigger happy the second they see an instance of "fuck" in a post, even though it's merely to emphasize a point.

I have seen no situations where this has happened. If you have, let me know and I'll be happy to review (and almost certainly overturn) those cases. Cursing is allowed as long as it is done appropriately and not used to insult, harass, or otherwise target other individuals.
